Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:A computational approach to template-based structure selection for protein-protein interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Missouri-Columbia is awarded a grant from the Faculty Early Career Development program (CAREER) to support research on macromolecular interactions, a central theme in functional genomics. The ability to predict protein-protein interactions has far reaching impact on understanding the molecular mechanisms of signal transduction and macromolecular assemblies, and ultimately on rational design of protein functions. Significant progress has been made on prediction of protein-protein interactions based on individual protein structures (referred to as protein-protein docking). However, lack of a reliable energy scoring functions to evaluate the binding tightness remains a critical problem in the field. Furthermore, with the rapid progress of the genome projects, it has become commonplace in plant, animal and human biology that homology-modeled structures are available for the study of protein pairs of interest, and the development of a systematic computational method for homologous protein-protein docking will have broad practical applications. This research will develop a new rigorously derived scoring function for protein-protein interactions based on the physical principles, and understanding why the new scoring function works will provide valuable insights into the development of other scoring functions. A new paradigm will also be developed and validated for predicting protein-protein interactions for cases in which only homology-modeled structures are available. The software package and test sets generated in this project will be available through the Zou lab website: http://zoulab.dalton.missouri.edu/.

As a part of her CAREER award, Dr. Zou will develop a true and unique interdisciplinary environment in her laboratory and in her class for excellence in research and education, particularly for underrepresented undergraduate and graduate students. Examples include developing a unique interdisciplinary curriculum and sponsoring undergraduate and pre-doctoral research fellowships/internships particularly for women and minority students. The PI also actively participates in scientific educations to local community and to Missouri high school students.

ProgramReference.Text: PROG FOR WOMEN AND UNDERREPRESENT GROUPS

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit.

 

During the funding period of this CAREER award, Dr. Xiaoqin Zou was promoted from an Assistant Professor to a Full Professor in the Department of Physics, Department of Biochemistry, Informatics Institute and Dalton Cardiovascular Research Center at the University of Missouri-Columbia. This project focused on structure prediction of protein-protein complexes. The ability to predict protein-protein interactions will have a far reaching impact on understanding the molecular mechanisms of signal transduction and macromolecular assemblies, and ultimately on rational design of protein functions and therapeutics. Significant progress has been made on prediction of protein-protein interactions based on individual protein structures (referred to as protein-protein docking). However, lack of a reliable energy scoring function to evaluate the binding tightness remains a critical problem in the field. Furthermore, with the rapid progress of the genome projects, it becomes more and more common in plant, animal and human biology studies that only homology-modeled structures are available for the protein pairs of interest. Thereby development of a systematic computational method for homologous protein-protein docking will have broad practical applications. Supported by this grant, Dr. Zou’s laboratory developed a novel scoring function to rank protein-protein complex structures based on the statistical mechanics principles, and a systematic strategy for protein-protein docking. We applied these methods to the CAPRI competitions (Critical Assessment of Prediction of Interactions, a highly competitive international competition designed to objectively assess the abilities in protein-protein docking prediction) and achieved excellent performance. We also developed a new protein-small protein (peptide) docking strategy based on homology and template modeling, integration of global rigid docking and local flexible docking, and the application of the proposed scoring paradigm to protein-peptide interactions. We constructed a series of webservers and databases for free public use. The servers, software packages and test sets generated in this project are available through the Zou lab website:

 http://zoulab.dalton.missouri.edu/

As a part of her CAREER award, Dr. Zou developed a true and unique interdisciplinary environment in her laboratory and in her class for excellence in research and education, including underrepresented undergraduate and graduate students. Examples include developing a unique interdisciplinary curriculum and sponsoring undergraduate and predoctoral research fellowships/internships particularly for women and minority students. The PI also actively participates in scientific educations to local community and to Missouri high school students.

 

Broader impact.

 

The easy-to-use webservers, software packages and benchmark datasets resulted from this project are freely available to the academic community to benefit both computational and experimental research studies, expanding our capabilities of in silico prediction, which has profound applications in biological sciences and biomedical sciences. The PI enthusiastically advocates for scientific education and research training for undergraduate and graduate students and postdocs, particularly for women and minority students. For example, she developed a unique interdisciplinary, problem-based learning, and writing-intensive curriculum for the NSF/IGERT training program. She also sponsored multiple undergraduate and predoctoral research fellowships/internships including NSF/REU fellowships. The PI also actively participates in scientific educations to local community and to Missouri high school students, including helping a Rock Bridge High School student win the Siemens Competition semifinalist award.

  

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2016
Modified by: Xiaoqin Zou

Images (1 of )
  • In silico prediction of protein-peptide complex structure is of great significance for peptide therapeutic development. Zou and co-workers developed a new method for protein-peptide complex structure prediction, based on the structure of a protein and the sequence of the peptide.
    Chengfei Yan, Xianjin Xu, and Xiaoqin Zou
    Copyrighted
    Xiaoqin Zou
    An example protein-peptide complex structure
  • Our predictions for four targets of protein-protein complexes in comparison with crystal structures (represented by tan ribbon). For each target, one binding partner (cyan) in the predicted structure was aligned to the corresponding part in the crystal structure; the other partner is green.
    Proteins: Structure, Function and Bioinformatics
    Copyrighted
    Xiaoqin Zou
    Examples of the predicted protein-protein complexes
  • Urea transporters are a family of membrane proteins that transport urea molecules across cell membranes and play important physiological roles. We simulated urea and water movement in the bacterial urea transporter, dvUT.
    Journal of Physical Chemistry B
    Copyrighted
    Xiaoqin Zou
    Water chain in the pore of Urea Transporter dvUT connecting the periplasm and cytoplasm
  • Chengfei Yan and Xiaoqin Zou describe a novel computational approach, ACCLUSTER, to predict peptide binding sites on protein surfaces by clustering chemical interactions. The method is assessed by diverse protein-peptide complexes, yielding very good performance.
    Journal of Computational Chemistry
    Copyrighted
    Xiaoqin Zou
    ACCLUSTER: A new approach for peptide binding site prediction
